title: New Louisiana ad hits governor over harassment case
text:
“Six women reported Johnny Anderson for sexual harassment and assault. The governor hired him anyway. I was his next victim,” Washington says in the ad. She says she was “harassed, groped, assaulted” by Anderson.

“When I was hurt, [Edwards] didn’t care. John Bel says, ‘People over politics.’ Not when you’re a woman like me,” Washington says.

The ad was paid for by Truth in Politics, a Republican 501(c)(4) that does not have to reveal its donors. It will air statewide and online, with a total of $750,000 media buy being put to air the ad.

Sexual harassment complaints had been made against Anderson as early as 2006 at a previous employer. Washington said Anderson harassed her in 2016 and 2017, and Anderson left his job in November 2017 after she complained about his actions to the Edwards administration. She later reached a settlement agreement with Anderson and the state in which neither admitted wrongdoing.

In an interview, Washington declined to detail how she was approached by the organization and wound up being featured in the ad.

“I believe it is important to speak up, and it is important to tell my story,” Washington told POLITICO. “I always wanted the truth to come out.”

She has spoken publicly about the alleged harassment before, in August of 2018 to The Times-Picayune.

Eric Holl, a spokesperson for Edwards' campaign, said Edwards' administration had treated Washington "with dignity and respect."

“Within hours of Ms. Washington’s allegations being brought to Gov. Edwards’ attention, Johnny Anderson's employment was ended," Holl said in a statement emailed after this story was first published. "Gov. Edwards believes Ms. Washington’s allegations, and he has a zero-tolerance policy for sexual harassment. Gov. Edwards implemented state government’s first uniform sexual harassment policy, championed legislation to support and empower victims of sexual harassment and assault, and has led the fights against human trafficking and domestic violence. Ms. Washington was not fired or asked to leave as a result of making her allegations. She submitted her letter of resignation weeks before her allegations were made. The governor’s administration has treated her with dignity and respect throughout this process.”

In the final weeks before the election, Republicans have ramped up their criticism of Edwards over Anderson. On Thursday, the Republican Governors Association’s affiliate, RGA Right Direction PAC, released a television ad that similarly attacked Edwards over his handling of Anderson's employment.

Most polling of the Oct. 12 primary has shown Edwards leading his two Republican competitors — Rep. Ralph Abraham and self-funding businessman Eddie Rispone — with Edwards just shy of the majority of the vote needed to clinch reelection without a runoff. If Edwards falls short of a majority of the votes cast, he will face the second-place candidate in another election on Nov. 16.

In recent days, Republicans have pushed hard to keep Edwards below 50 percent. President Donald Trump tweeted twice about the race this week, pleading with his Louisiana followers to vote for either Abraham or Rispone. "A Republican will win if you can force a runoff!" he posted.

Meanwhile, Vice President Mike Pence is reportedly planning a trip to the state this weekend.
